text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single full-page miniature above a single column of three lines of text; wide margins at right and left filled with delicate gold foliate scrolls

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata with alternating red and blue rubrics and line fillers

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf defines background pattern and architectural finials, marking sacred importance; deep blue millefleur field suggests heavenly space; red and blue garments alternate to denote rank; layered white highlights model drapery; pigment layers remain well preserved with minimal darkening.

features: Central vertical emphasis on the tall cylindrical keep
Leftward procession of clerical figures balanced by horizontal register of fishermen below
Architectural framing with pinnacles and spandrels encloses the scene
Diagonals in the fishing boats create dynamic counterpoint to the vertical tower

decorative_elements: Millefleur background dotted with stylized foliage
Gothic micro-architectural frame with crocketed pinnacles
Gold punched dots in the sky field
Marginal vine scroll with gold leaves

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine quill outlines of even weight for figures and architecture
drawing_technique.shading_method: No hatching; volume conveyed by layered pigments and white highlights
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling and overlapping without true linear perspective

content_theme.scene_description: A single full-page miniature depicts a bishop or archangel-like cleric carrying a crozier leading six tonsured monks in long gowns from left to right toward the open gate of a pink and grey fortified castle. Two seated figures in red vestments observe from a central balcony; on the right parapet a servant tends to a child. Below on dark green water, four fishermen in two boats haul a large, finely rendered net brimming with fish. The tall cylindrical keep dominates the composition; its crenellated walls and turrets are picked out in burnished gold and pink lead pigment. The clerical party wears red and blue robes, some holding books as they process into the city. Depth is suggested by overlapping boats and receding arcade beneath the tower. Costume details include the leader’s mitre-like headgear, monks’ tonsures, and fishermen’s coifs. The net and water have precise linework, while the millefleur sky and gold punched dots indicate divine space. Overall, the image emphasizes the clerical entry’s hierarchical importance contrasted with secular labor below.

religious: Six monks or clerics in gowns and tonsures

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, smooth and evenly prepared; faint plummet ruling visible
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vibrant pigments with minimal flaking; slight browning of margins; gold leaf largely intact; minor abrasion in lower right corner
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso beneath gold leaf in background pattern
Underdrawing visible under UV in figures
Punch-work decoration in gold leaf finials
Consistent quire structure indicated by prick-marks

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This mid-14th-century illumination, likely produced in a Parisian workshop, exemplifies the Gothic courtly style favored by elite patrons. The hierarchical composition—towering central keep and processional clerics—underscores the sacred narrative’s primacy, while the lower register of fishermen visually anchors the scene in everyday life, perhaps alluding to the apostolic metaphor of ‘fishers of men.’ The extensive use of ultramarine and burnished gold leaf signals both spiritual significance and the patron’s affluence. Technically, the artist employed a confident underdrawing, even quill outlines, and layered pigments with white highlighting to model forms—practices characteristic of high-quality book illumination in Paris circa 1340–1350. The millefleur background and micro-architectural frame with punched gold reflect the influence of the so-called ‘Style XIII’ prevalent under Philip VI. Iconographically, the depiction of a bishop leading monks into a fortified city may represent the translation of a saint’s relics, set against a fortified, almost heavenly Jerusalem. Compared to contemporaneous works such as the Psalter of Blanche of Castile, this miniature innovates by integrating a secular fishing scene, thus reinforcing the medieval dialectic between divine authority and worldly labor. Overall, the manuscript functions as both a devotional tool and a display of status, marrying technical sophistication with rich symbolic layering.
